rev.comment: /* Court trials of state officials accused of corruption */
rev.diff:
Line 559: Line 559:
===Court trials of state officials accused of corruption===
===Court trials of state officials accused of corruption===
{{main|Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution}}
{{main|Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution}}
â
The ousting of Mubarak was followed by a series of arrests of, and / or imposed travel bans on high profile figures on charges of causing the death of 300-500 demonstrators, and the injury of 5,000 more, as well as charges of [[embezzlement]], [[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]], [[money laundry]], and [[Human rights abuses|abuse of human rights]]. Among these figures are Mubarak himself, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]], his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]], his son [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], the former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], the former Housing Minister Ahmed El-Maghrabi, the former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]] and the former Secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Al-Ahram Weekly |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's ousting was also followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians<ref>{{cite news|first=Phillip |last=Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts |publisher=Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=ÙØµØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ: Ø´Ø®ØµÙØ© ÙØ¨ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ±Ø¦Ø§Ø³Ø© Ø£ÙØ¯Øª ÙÙ Ø£Ù "ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù" ÙÙ ÙØªØ±Ø´Ø­ ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ Ø³ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¨Ø¯ÙÙ |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date=|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> On 28 February 2011, Egypt's top prosecutor ordered an asset freeze for Mubarak and his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html |title=Egypt Issues Travel Ban, Asset Freeze on Mubarak |publisher=Voice of America |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> This was followed by arrest warrants, travel bans and judicial orders to freeze the assets of other known public figures, including the former Speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former Speaker of the Higher Legislative Body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak - then what? |publisher=Ahram Online |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Arrest warrants were also issued against some public figures who left the country with the outbreak of the revolution. These warrants were issued on allegations of financial misappropriations, rather than human rights abuses. Among these public figures are [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], the former Minister of Trade and Industry and Hussein Salem, a business tycoon. Salem is believed to have left for Dubai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
+
The ousting of Mubarak was followed by a series of arrests of, and / or imposed travel bans on high profile figures on charges of causing the death of 300-500 demonstrators, and the injury of 5,000 more, as well as charges of [[embezzlement]], [[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]], [[money laundry]], and [[Human rights abuses|abuse of human rights]]. Among these figures are Mubarak himself, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]], his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]], his son [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], the former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], the former Housing Minister Ahmed El-Maghrabi, the former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]] and the former Secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Al-Ahram Weekly |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's ousting was also followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians<ref>{{cite news|first=Phillip |last=Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts |publisher=Guardian |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=16 ordered an asset freeze for Mubarak and his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html |title=Egypt Issues Travel Ban, Asset Freeze on Mubarak |publisher=Voice of America |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> This was followed by arrest warrants, travel bans and judicial orders to freeze the assets of other known public figures, including the former Speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former Speaker of the Higher Legislative Body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak - then what? |publisher=Ahram Online |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Arrest warrants were also issued against some public figures who left the country with the outbreak of the revolution. These warrants were issued on allegations of financial misappropriations, rather than human rights abuses. Among these public figures are [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], the former Minister of Trade and Industry and [[Hussein Salem]], a business tycoon. Salem is believed to have left for Dubai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
Trials of the accused officials started on 5 March 2011 when the former Interior Minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 ÙØ§Ø±Ø³.. Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> The trials of el-Adli and other public figures are expected to run a lengthy course.
Trials of the accused officials started on 5 March 2011 when the former Interior Minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 ÙØ§Ø±Ø³..
